name: Teknologi for integrerte operasjoner og semantisk web

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is the purpose of the Common Language Specification?
answers: Ensure compliance between different .NET languages.
Make sure a specific language can be compiled to a common assembly using Visual Studio
Abstract the language specific implementation details from other users of .NET.
Compile MSIL code in assemblies to machine code when the code is executed.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is "boxing"?
answers: When you have a private variable in a class (a field), that variable is said to be "boxed"
If you call a method with a reference type parameter, that parameter is "boxed" before it is sent to the method.
If you assign a value type to a reference type variable, the value type is said to be "boxed" into the reference type.
Boxing occurs when you use auto-properties in C#.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is an assembly, and what does it contain?
answers: A Visual Studio project file. It contains the information about the project and how it should be assembled.
A file from the Base Class Library (BCL). It contains methods that can be used by others.
A collection of source code files in the Assembly language. These are the files that are used by the Common Language Specification.
A DLL file that is made from compiling C# source code. It contains the MSIL code that is run by the Common Language Runtime, metadata about the code and any resources needed

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What services are provided by the CLR (Common Language Runtime), as presented in the syllabus?
answers: Managing threads
C# and VB language JIT compilation
Documentation
Memory management
Exception handling
Registry cleanup
Multicore manager
Code security

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What will the following code print if it is run?
answers: "win"
"fail"
The answer depends on the architecture of the computer (32 or 64 bit).
The code does not compile and cannot be run; nothing is printed.

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is the purpose of a Namespace?
answers: To specify what classes should go in what assemblies
To give a name to your program
To avoid name collisions
None of these

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is an event?
answers: A special method on Graphical User Interface (GUI) controls
A way of getting notified of a given happening
A branch statement in code. Similar to the switch … case statement
The only way to know when a class is finished working

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is the CLR (Common Language Runtime)?
answers: The core of Visual Studio that is common for running all the .NET languages (C#, VB.NET, F#)
Central component in the Base Class Library (BCL)
The engine in the .NET Framework for executing applications on any operating system
None of the above

questions.question: [C# and .NET] What is a Property in a class?
answers: A piece of metadata – information about the class that you can specify when writing the class.
A set of methods that can be used like a class field by clients, but is actually getter and setter methods.
A property is given in angle brackets "[]" above the class name, and gives information about the class.
A property is a public field in a class. This exposes information to clients of the class.

questions.question: [WCF] What is a Web Service?
answers: It is a way for companies to expose services to user on the Internet. Facebook is an example of a Web Service.
It is computer programs for inter-machine communication over a network
It is a way to get information from a company over the http protocol
A standard for inter-process communcation in a web server
It is used to give commands into a web server to alter the behavior of the server

questions.question: [WCF] What is the Windows Communcation Foundation?
answers: It is a part of the .Net framework that is used for creating Graphical User Interfaces (GUI)
It is the network part of the .NET framework
It is a unified plattform for distributed computing using .NET
It is a class library for Instant Messaging for .NET
It is the system used by Microsoft to communicate on the Internet

questions.question: [WCF] What langage is WSDL (Web Service Description Langauge) based on?
answers: SOA
WCF
C#
XML
SOAP
None of these

questions.question: [WCF] What option below best describes SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol)?
answers: A protocol for Instant Messaging
A wrapper for other messages. It is used to hide the content for others on the network.
A protocol for sending control messages when objects are exchanged using some other protocol. This is called a out of band protocol.
A protocol for exchanging information over any medium
The protocol used for object access in Windows Communication Foundation

questions.question: [WCF] The text snippet above is taken from a WCF configuration file. What is the name of the .NET interface that defines the custom operations exposed by this web service?
answers: Service1 [1]
IMetadataExchange[2]
IOrdbokService[3]
wsHttpBinding[4]
Ordbokservice[5]
2 and 3
None of these

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] In state machine workflows, can states be repeated? I.e. can you go from state A to B, then back to A?
answers: Yes
No
Only if the workflow is not defined to be long-lived
Only if the workflow is a console application

questions.question: [Windows Workflow Foundation] What is true about Windows Workflow Foundation?
answers: Workflows are layed out in a Visual Designer
The activities you can choose from are limited to the ones that ship with Workflow Foundation
There are only two types of workflows
The workflow is not a stand-alone application
Any workflow can be run by a Runtime Service
WF is part of .NET 2.0
The compiled Workflow is executed by the Runtime Engine
A WF activity is just a normal class

questions.question: [RTC] Real time communication is:
answers: Synchronious, same place
Asyncronious, same place
Synchronious, different place
Asyncronious, different place

questions.question: [RTC] What functions/services does SIP (Session Initiation Protocol) provide?  (select all that applies)
answers: User Interface (displaying call progress to the user)
Data Transfer (transferring the voice and video data over the network)
User Capabilities (determines codecs, encryption capabilities etc. of the client devices)
Voice and video compression (for better utilization of the network)
Session Management (call transfer, session termination etc.)
Command line interface (provides command line tools for conversation setup)

questions.question: [RTC] What is VoIP?
answers: Voice In Person; a system for telepresence
A system for transmitting volume information about a sound stream, Volume Information Protocol
Volatile Internet Presence. A protocol for communication over the unstable parts of the Internet
Voice Over Internet Protocol. A protocol for doing voice communication over the Internet

questions.question: [RTC] What is the responsibility of audio and video codecs?
answers: Convert the audio or video data into a form that is transmittable over the network.
Compress and decompress the audio or video data to make it smaller for storage or network transfer.
Codecs are only used to compress the audio and video data. Descramblers uncompress it.
A codec is the SIP (Session Initiation Protocol) endpoint on the machine, taking care of sending and receiving SIP messages.
None of these.

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What role does XML play in the Semantic Web?
answers: Definition of OWL
Serialization of OWL ontology models
Unified format for ontology mapping
Representation of ontology layout
Semantic markup language for the Semantic Web

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What is an ontology?
answers: Description of a language for defining domain models
Abstract description of commonly accepted phenomena of a domain
Set of principles for application interoperability
Domain experts’ tacit knowledge of the domain

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] We often distinguish between top-level ontologies, application ontologies, domain ontologies and task ontologies. Which type of ontology is the most likely to change?
answers: Top-level ontologies
Application ontologies
Domain ontologies
Task ontologies

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What does URI stand for?
answers: Unique Role Identification
Uniform Resource Identifiers
Unmarked Record Interoperability
Unified Resource Integration

questions.question: [SemWeb Intro] What is the purpose of namespaces in the Semantic Web?
answers: namespaces are shorthand notations for URIrefs
a namespace identifies a particular resource
namespaces specify rules for naming resources
namespaces associated with URIrefs disambiguate duplicate element names.

questions.question: [Ontology languages] What is a property in RDF?
answers: URI reference
The type of a resource
Mapping from RDF resources to OWL classes
Binary relation between subjects and objects

questions.question: [Ontology languages] What is not supported in RDF or RDFS?
answers: Cardinality constraints
Classes
Definition of subclasses
Definition of range of properties

questions.question: [Ontology languages] What is the type property used for in RDF?
answers: Defining a resource as an instance of a class
Defining subclass relationships
Defining a resource as a specialization of another resource
Defining an alias for a resource
Defining a label for a resource

questions.question: [Ontology languages] Which is the most expressive language that retains computational completeness and decidability?
answers: XML
RDF
RDFS
OWL DL
OWL Full

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is topmost class in OWL
answers: Thing
Object
Resource
Element
There is no fixed topmost class in OWL

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What are the most important modeling primitives in OWL
answers: Resources, relations and attributes
Classes, properties and individuals
Classes and resources
Objects, types and properties
Subjects, objects and properties

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is not true about classes in OWL?
answers: All classes may have instances
Instances of superclasses are always instances of the class
Instances of subclasses are always instances of the class
OWL classes are subclasses of RDF classes

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is the formal interpretation of a class in OWL DL?
answers: set of OWL statements describing the class
set of instances of the class
set of resources in RDF
set of objects in the interpretation domain
set of object pairs in the interpretation domain

questions.question: [OWL Modelling] What is the formal interpretation of a property in OWL DL?
answers: set of objects in the domain
set of object pairs in the domain
set of n-ary object tuples in the domain
interpretation of domain and range of property
set of resource tuples in RDF

questions.question: [Abstract OWL] What can we not infer from these statements
answers: Students are humans
All students are smart persons
SecretOfSemanticWeb is a book
Humans do not write more than one book
All students write a thesis

questions.question: [Ontology Engineering] Term t is the most frequent term in document D, but its tf.idf score for document D is equal to 0.  How can that be?
answers: Term t does not appear in any other document of the collection
Term t appears in all other documents of the collection
There are no terms in D that are frequent enough to have a tf.idf score above 0.
There are other documents that have higher frequencies of t than D.

questions.question: [Ontology Applications] How is the ontology used to rank documents in the Squirrel search application?
answers: The ontology boosts documents on topics the user is interested in
The ontology is used as a controlled search vocabulary
The ontology is used to construct semantic indices instead of traditional ones
The ontology boosts documents that address the most ontology concepts

questions.question: [Ontology Applications] What parts of the ontologies are mostly used for information retrieval?
answers: Properties and property hierarchies
Classes and their data properties
Object properties and data properties
Classes and class hierarchies
